content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

David Lee: I was born in Shanghai, China, but I moved to the United States with my family when I was about five years old. We settled in Seattle, Washington, where I grew up. My parents didn't have a lot of formal education—my father only finished middle school, and my mother didn't finish high school either. But they worked hard, especially my mother, who took on multiple jobs to support our family. I remember growing up in a small apartment, and we didn't have much, but we had love and a strong sense of family. I was always encouraged to study and do well in school, even if they didn't have the means to provide me with many resources. I went to public school, and I was pretty good at math and science. I ended up going to college on a scholarship, and later I earned a graduate degree in engineering. I've been working full time for the past ten years, and I'm married now with two kids. Life hasn't always been easy, but I've always believed in working hard and making the most of the opportunities I've had.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

David Lee: Yes, there was definitely a crossroads. I was about 18, right after finishing high school, and I had two options: go to a local community college or take a job at a manufacturing plant that offered to hire me on the spot. My parents were struggling financially, and they really needed the income. I felt torn because I knew the job would provide stability, but I also knew that if I didn't go to college, I might be stuck in that same cycle of limited opportunities. I remember talking to my mother late one night, and she said something that stuck with me: 'If you don't take this chance, you might regret it for the rest of your life.' That night, I decided to go to community college. It wasn't easy—working part-time while going to school, sometimes staying up late to study, but I made it through. I eventually transferred to a four-year university and earned my degree. That decision shaped everything that came after, and I've never looked back.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

David Lee: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made easily. I had to weigh the immediate needs of my family against the long-term possibilities for myself. In the end, I realized that while I couldn't control the circumstances I was born into, I could control the decisions I made. That moment taught me the value of education and the importance of thinking beyond the present. It wasn't just about me—it was about the future I wanted for my family too. I made the choice, and it was the right one, even though it wasn't the easy one.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

David Lee: Absolutely. I remember talking to a teacher at my high school, Mr. Chen, who saw potential in me even when I didn't see it in myself. He encouraged me to apply for scholarships and even helped me write my application essays. Without his support, I might not have had the confidence to pursue college. There were also local organizations that offered tutoring and mentorship programs for students from low-income families. I think if more people and organizations had reached out to kids like me, it could have made a huge difference. It wasn't just about money—it was about having someone believe in you and show you a path forward.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

David Lee: Yes, I'm married to my wife, Mei, who is also from China. We met in college, actually—she was studying business, and I was in engineering. We got married right after we graduated, and we've been together for over ten years now. We have two kids: a daughter, Lily, who's eight, and a son, Ethan, who's five. They're both bilingual, speaking both English and Mandarin, which I think is really important for them to connect with their heritage. Mei works part-time as a translator, which helps support our family, and I work full-time as a civil engineer. We live in the same neighborhood I grew up in, which feels like a full circle in a way. It's not always easy balancing work and family life, especially with two kids, but we make it work. Mei and I have a strong partnership, and we both believe in working hard and providing the best for our children. I think the values my parents instilled in me—like the importance of education, hard work, and family—have really shaped how I raise my kids, and I hope they carry those values with them as they grow up.

Going through these interview questions brought back a lot of memories and reflections about my journey. It was interesting to look back at my life from the beginning, from my childhood in Shanghai to growing up in Seattle, and how my parents' sacrifices shaped my path. Thinking about the crossroads I faced at 18 made me realize how pivotal that decision was—not just for me, but for my family's future. I'm grateful for the support I received from teachers like Mr. Chen and organizations that believed in me when I didn't believe in myself. Now, as a father and husband, I see how the values I was raised with—hard work, education, and family—continue to guide me in raising my children. It's amazing how the past continues to shape the present, and I'm proud of the person I've become through all of it.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

David Lee: My parents are still living in Seattle, and they've been a huge part of our lives. My father, although he didn't have much formal education, has always been a hard worker. He retired from a factory job a few years ago, but he still helps out around the house and keeps busy with gardening and fixing things. My mother, on the other hand, has always been the heart of our family. She's the one who kept us going through tough times, and even now, she's always there to offer advice or help with the kids. Our relationship is very close, and I try to spend as much time with them as I can. They've sacrificed so much for my brother and me, and I want them to know how grateful I am. My brother, Jason, is a few years older than me, and he's living in San Francisco now. He works in IT and has a family of his own. We don't see each other as often as we'd like, but we stay in touch. He's always been a big support to me, and I admire the way he's built his life. It's amazing how different our paths have been, but I think we both share the same values—hard work, family, and making the most of what we have.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

David Lee: There are a few friends from college and high school who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who was my roommate in college. She's a nurse now, and she's been a great support system for me, especially when I was starting out in my career. We've been friends for over 20 years, and even though we don't see each other as often as we'd like, we stay in touch through calls and messages. Another person who's had a big impact on my life is my wife's best friend, Rachel. She's been like a sister to me, and she's always there with advice or just a listening ear. I think it's important to have people in your life who aren't related by blood but still care deeply about you. They've helped me through tough times and celebrated my successes, and I'm really grateful for their presence in my life.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

David Lee: I live in a neighborhood in Seattle called Capitol Hill, which is pretty diverse and has a lot of character. There are a mix of old and new buildings, lots of cafes, parks, and community centers. It's a pretty walkable area, and I like that I can walk to work or take a short bus ride if I need to. The community here is very supportive, and there are a lot of local events and festivals throughout the year that bring people together. I've been involved in a few neighborhood groups, like a local gardening club that my father and I started with some other retirees. It's a great way to stay connected and give back. I also like that there are a lot of schools and libraries nearby, which is important for my kids. Even though the cost of living here is high, I think it's worth it for the quality of life and the sense of community. It feels like a place where people care about each other, and I'm proud to be raising my kids here.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

David Lee: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. Capitol Hill has a strong sense of community, and people look out for each other. I've never had any real issues with crime, and the local police department is pretty responsive when needed. I also appreciate how the neighborhood has a lot of street lighting and well-maintained public spaces, which makes me feel secure, especially when walking with the kids after school. There's a real sense of belonging here, and I think that contributes to the safety. Of course, no place is perfect, but overall, I feel confident that my family is in a good, safe environment.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

David Lee: Living here has definitely had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, the community feels like a second family. There are always neighbors who stop by to check on us, especially when we're busy with the kids or working late. The schools are great, and I've seen my kids grow up in an environment that values education and creativity. But there are challenges too. The cost of living is high, and sometimes it feels like we're constantly balancing budgets—whether it's for groceries, extracurricular activities for the kids, or even just keeping up with the bills. I also miss the quiet of the suburbs sometimes, where you can hear birds chirping instead of the constant hum of traffic. But overall, I think the pros outweigh the cons. I love that my kids have access to so many opportunities, and that I can walk to work or grab a cup of coffee at one of the local cafes. It's a busy life, but it's a life I'm proud of.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood brought up a lot of feelings about how far I've come and how much I value the people and place I call home. Talking about my wife, kids, and parents reminded me of how important family is to me, and how the values I grew up with—like hard work and education—continue to shape the way I raise my children. When I described my neighborhood, it made me appreciate the sense of community and safety that Capitol Hill offers, especially for my kids. It also made me reflect on the balance between the challenges of living in a high-cost area and the opportunities and connections that come with it. Overall, it was a meaningful exercise to look back on these aspects of my life and realize how much they contribute to who I am today.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

David Lee: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on work deadlines and the kids' schedules. I usually start my week on Monday with a morning routine—getting the kids ready for school, making breakfast, and then heading to work. I work as a civil engineer, so my days can be long and sometimes unpredictable. I'm often on site or in meetings, but I try to leave work around 6 or 7 p.m. to be home for dinner. On weekdays, I usually have some kind of extracurricular activity with the kids—whether it's soccer, music lessons, or a community event. On the weekends, we like to go to the park, visit family, or have a quiet day at home. My wife and I also try to take some time for ourselves, like going out for coffee or a walk. It's not always perfect, but I think the balance works for us. What I love most is that even though life is busy, I feel like I'm present for the important moments with my kids and family, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

David Lee: I work as a civil engineer for a mid-sized firm here in Seattle, specializing in infrastructure projects like roads, bridges, and public transit systems. I typically work a standard 40-hour week, though the hours can vary depending on the project timeline. Most days, I start around 7:30 a.m., and I'm usually in the office by 8:30. My job involves a mix of design, planning, and on-site inspections, so I spend a good portion of my week in meetings or reviewing blueprints, but I also get out into the field quite a bit. I enjoy the hands-on aspect of it—seeing a project go from a concept on paper to something tangible that people use every day. I work until around 6 or 7 p.m., and then I head home to be with the family. The job is demanding, but I find it rewarding because it allows me to contribute to something bigger than myself, and I know my work helps shape the community my kids will grow up in.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

David Lee: Outside of work and family, I have a few routines that help me stay grounded. I try to exercise at least a few times a week, usually going for runs in the mornings before the kids are up or hitting the gym after work. I also enjoy cooking, especially on weekends when I can take my time experimenting with new recipes. It's a way for me to unwind and connect with my family, since we all sit down for meals together. I also make it a point to read a bit every night, whether it's a novel or something related to my work. It helps me relax and keep my mind sharp. Another thing I do is volunteer with a local community center that offers after-school programs for kids from low-income families. It's a small way to give back, and it reminds me of the support I received when I was younger. It's not always easy to juggle everything, but these little routines help me stay balanced and focused on what really matters.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

David Lee: One of the recent changes to my daily routine has been adjusting to my kids' evolving schedules as they've gotten older. My daughter, Lily, started middle school this year, and it's been a big transition for her—and for me, as a parent. She's been busier with homework and extracurriculars, so I've had to be more involved in helping her manage her time. I've started setting aside specific times each evening to sit down with her and go over her assignments, which has been a nice way to stay connected and support her learning. On the flip side, my son, Ethan, has started kindergarten, and that's brought a new rhythm to our mornings. We've had to get up earlier and streamline our routines so we can get him out the door on time. It's been a bit of a learning curve, but I've found that these changes have brought us closer as a family. I also started taking evening walks with my wife a few times a week to decompress after the kids are in bed. It's a small thing, but it's been a great way to reconnect and talk about everything that's been on our minds. Life is always changing, and I think it's important to adapt and find new ways to keep things balanced.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

David Lee: A typical weekday during the school year for my kids starts pretty early. My daughter, Lily, usually gets up at 6:30 a.m., and my son, Ethan, a little later, around 7:00 a.m. We have a morning routine where we all have breakfast together, and then they get ready for school. Lily walks to her middle school, which is about a 15-minute walk away, while Ethan takes the bus. After school, Lily has soccer practice on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays, and she also has a weekly homework club at the library on Tuesdays. I try to pick her up after practice and help her with her homework in the evening. Ethan, on the other hand, has a music class on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and he also joins a small group for kids who need extra support with reading. After school, we usually have dinner together as a family, and then the kids either do some extra reading or play games. I think it's important for them to have structure, but also to have time to be kids. I also make sure they have some quiet time before bed, whether it's reading a book or just talking about their day. It's a busy schedule, but I see how it's helping them grow and stay engaged with their education.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and places around me. Thinking about my family, especially my wife, kids, and parents, reminded me of how deeply rooted my values are—hard work, education, and family. It's amazing how those values, instilled in me during my childhood, continue to guide me in raising my children today. When I described my neighborhood, it made me appreciate the sense of community and safety that Capitol Hill offers, especially for my kids. It also made me reflect on the balance between the challenges of living in a high-cost area and the opportunities and connections that come with it. Overall, it was a meaningful exercise to look back on these aspects of my life and realize how much they contribute to who I am today. I feel grateful for the support I've received from my family, friends, and community, and I hope to pass on the same values and support to my children as they grow up.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

David Lee: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty fortunate. I've always tried to maintain a decent level of fitness, mostly through running and lifting weights at the gym a few times a week. I used to play basketball in college, and even though I haven't kept up with that as much as I'd like, I still enjoy being active. I do have a few minor health issues—like occasional back pain from sitting at a desk for long hours, and I've had to be careful with my diet over the years, especially with the stress of work and family life. I've also had to manage some seasonal allergies, which can be a bit of a nuisance, but nothing too serious. I try to eat healthy, mostly focusing on lean proteins, vegetables, and whole grains, though I'll admit I do have a weakness for Chinese food, especially when I'm feeling down or need a pick-me-up. I also make sure to get enough sleep, even if it's not always easy with two kids and a busy work schedule. Overall, I feel pretty good, and I think staying active and eating well has helped me avoid any major health problems so far. I've also started seeing a therapist occasionally to help with stress management, which I think is really important for maintaining both mental and physical well-being.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

David Lee: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine—like running in the mornings or lifting weights a few times a week. It's something I can count on, even when life gets busy. Also, having a supportive family helps. My wife and kids are always encouraging me to take care of myself, whether it's reminding me to eat a healthy meal or to take a break when I need it. On the flip side, what makes it hard is the constant juggling of work, family, and personal time. There are days when I'm so caught up in deadlines or helping the kids with homework that I forget to take care of myself. I've also found that stress can take a toll, especially when things feel overwhelming. But I've learned that even small things—like taking a walk after work or having a quiet moment with a cup of tea—can make a big difference. It's not always perfect, but I try to stay mindful of my health because I know it's the foundation for everything else in life.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

David Lee: In the past two years, I actually had a minor knee injury from playing soccer with some friends at a local park. It wasn't anything serious, but I did sprain it slightly during a game, and it took a few weeks to heal properly. I had to take a break from running for a while, which was tough because I rely on that as a way to clear my mind. I saw a physical therapist for a couple of sessions, and they helped me strengthen the muscles around my knee to prevent future issues. It was a reminder that even small injuries can disrupt your routine, but it also made me more mindful of warming up properly and listening to my body. Other than that, I haven't had any major health issues. I've been pretty consistent with my check-ups, and my doctor says I'm in good shape for my age. It's funny, though—I think that injury made me realize how important it is to take care of myself, not just for my kids, but for me too. I've started incorporating more stretching into my routine now, and I'm even more careful about pacing myself during physical activities.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

David Lee: Honestly, the knee injury did slow me down a bit at first, especially since I was used to being active every day. There were a few days where I felt frustrated because I couldn't run or lift weights like I normally do, and I worried it might affect my work or my ability to keep up with the kids. But I realized that taking a step back wasn't a weakness—it was a necessary part of recovery. I adjusted my routine, focusing more on low-impact exercises like swimming and walking, and I made sure to involve the kids in some of those activities too. It actually became a bonding moment for us, especially with Ethan, who loves to walk with me after school. In the end, it didn't stop me from working or caring for my family; if anything, it reminded me that health is something I need to prioritize, not just for myself, but for everyone who depends on me. I think that experience made me more resilient and more aware of how small changes can have a big impact on my overall well-being.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

David Lee: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel really grounded and grateful, and other days I feel the weight of everything life throws at you. With the kids growing up so fast, it's amazing how quickly time passes. I've been trying to be more present, whether it's during dinner conversations, bedtime stories, or just sitting quietly with my wife after the kids are asleep. I think the pandemic really made me realize how important it is to cherish the little moments. I've also been reflecting a lot on my own journey—how far I've come from that small apartment in Seattle, and how much my parents' sacrifices have shaped who I am today. There's a sense of responsibility I feel, not just as a father and husband, but as someone who wants to set a good example for my kids. I've been trying to balance that with being my own person, pursuing my interests, and making sure I don't lose myself in the chaos of everyday life. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to find joy in the everyday things—like a good cup of coffee, a walk in the park, or even just a quiet moment with my family.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my life has changed over the years, especially in terms of my family, health, and daily routines. Thinking about the recent changes in my kids' schedules reminded me how quickly they're growing up and how important it is to stay involved in their lives. It also made me realize how much I've adapted to the challenges of being a working parent, finding balance between my job, family, and personal health. When I talked about my health, it brought up how much I've come to value taking care of myself—not just for me, but for my family too. I've learned that even small things, like a walk after work or a few minutes of quiet reflection, can make a big difference in how I feel and how I show up for the people I love. It's amazing how much my journey has shaped me, and I'm grateful for every step of the way.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

David Lee: Honestly, I've had my share of tough moments, especially when I was younger and feeling the pressure of balancing work, family, and my own self-doubt. There were times when I felt overwhelmed, especially during those long nights working on projects or helping the kids with homework while trying to keep my own head above water. I think the biggest challenge for me has been managing stress without letting it consume me. I used to push through everything on my own, thinking that showing weakness was a sign of failure. But over the years, I've learned that it's okay to ask for help, whether it's from my wife, friends, or even a therapist. I've started talking more openly about how I feel, and that's helped me feel less isolated. I still have days when I feel anxious or down, but I've developed coping strategies—like taking time for myself, staying active, and reminding myself of the progress I've made. I think the key is not to ignore those feelings but to face them head-on and find healthy ways to deal with them. I'm not perfect, but I'm learning, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

David Lee: For my family, the past year has been a mix of growth, challenges, and moments of deep connection. Mei has been doing well, though she's been juggling her part-time work with helping me with the kids, especially with Lily's transition to middle school. She's been amazing, as always, but I can tell she's been stretched thin at times. The kids, too, have been going through their own changes—Lily is more independent now, which is great, but also means she's starting to push boundaries, and Ethan is becoming more curious about the world around him. We've had our share of late nights and early mornings, but I think we've all learned to lean on each other more than ever. There were moments when I worried about how we'd keep up with everything, but I've come to realize that it's not about perfection—it's about showing up for each other, even when life feels overwhelming. I'm proud of how we've navigated this year together, and I know we're stronger because of it.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

David Lee: For me, religion or spirituality hasn't been a central part of my life, though I respect the role it plays for others. Growing up, my family didn't practice any specific faith, and I never felt a need to fill that void with something formal. Instead, I've found my sense of purpose and meaning in the values my parents instilled in me—hard work, family, and education. I think of my parents' sacrifices as a kind of spiritual foundation, a quiet but powerful force that guides me. I also find meaning in the small, everyday moments: the way my kids laugh, the way my wife and I support each other, or even the way the neighborhood feels like home. I don't think of it as spirituality in the traditional sense, but I do believe in something bigger than myself, something that connects us all. I guess I'm more of a believer in the human spirit and the power of love and resilience.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

David Lee: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I find that it can be a bit overwhelming with all the noise and comparisons, and I've always preferred more personal, face-to-face connections. That said, I do use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with family and old friends, especially those who live far away like my brother in San Francisco. I also follow a few local community pages in Capitol Hill to keep up with neighborhood events and initiatives. I think it's important to stay connected, but I've learned that I don't need to be constantly online to feel part of the world. I much prefer spending time with my family, reading, or going for a run. When I do use social media, it's more about staying in touch than about sharing my life with a wider audience. I think that's why I've never felt the need to be on Instagram or other more visually driven platforms—it just doesn't feel like the right fit for me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

David Lee: Honestly, I haven't really relied on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I think I've always leaned more on the people I know in real life—my wife, my family, my friends. When things got really tough, like when I was deciding whether to go to college or take the job, it was my mom's words and the support from teachers like Mr. Chen that helped me through. I think social media can be a tool, but it's not the same as having someone right there, face-to-face, who truly understands what you're going through. That said, I do appreciate the way Facebook has helped me stay connected with people who matter, even if I don't use it for support in the way some others might. It's more about staying in touch than about finding help, and I think that's enough for me.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and emotional well-being have shaped my life in recent years. Talking about my knee injury reminded me of how even small setbacks can disrupt your routine, but also how they can be turning points for growth and awareness. It made me realize how important it is to take care of myself—not just for me, but for my family too. When I discussed my feelings about depression and anxiety, it brought up how much I've learned to lean on my wife, friends, and even a therapist to help manage the stress of everyday life. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but now I see that asking for help is a strength, not a weakness. It also made me think about how my family has been through their own challenges, and how we've all learned to support each other through the ups and downs. I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned about health, resilience, and the importance of being present for the people I love.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

David Lee: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have been a bit higher than usual, mostly due to the added responsibilities of Lily starting middle school and the ongoing challenges of balancing work and family life. There are days when I feel like I'm constantly running between tasks, and I worry I'm not giving enough attention to any one thing. But I've been working on developing better coping strategies. One thing that's helped is setting aside specific times to unwind—whether it's a quiet evening walk with Mei, reading a book, or even just sitting on the porch and watching the kids play. I've also started journaling more, which has been a great way to process my thoughts and emotions. I used to think that stress was something I had to push through on my own, but I've come to realize that it's okay to take a step back and take care of myself. I've also leaned more on my support system—talking to Mei, my friends, or even just taking a few deep breaths when things feel overwhelming. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that managing stress isn't about eliminating it completely, but about finding ways to live with it and not let it control me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

David Lee: Last month, our biggest expenses were definitely related to the kids' activities and education. Lily's middle school has a lot of extracurricular fees—soccer, homework club, and even some field trips. Ethan's music lessons and the reading support group also add up. Then there's the cost of groceries, which has been a bit higher than usual because we've been trying to eat healthier and include more organic options. Utilities and car payments are also regular expenses, and with the cost of living in Seattle, those can be a strain. I also set aside money for savings and emergencies, which is something I've been really focused on lately. It's not always easy to track every dollar, but I try to be as mindful as possible. Mei and I have a budget spreadsheet that we update weekly, and we make sure to review it together to stay on top of things. It's a balancing act, but I think it's important to plan ahead so we can provide the best for our kids without sacrificing our own well-being.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

David Lee: Our household spent roughly around $5,500 last month, which is actually a bit higher than usual. Typically, we hover around $4,800 to $5,200 per month. The increase this time was mostly due to Lily's school having a special field trip that required a fee, and we also had to replace the family car's tires, which we hadn't planned for. On a regular month, our biggest expenses are the kids' activities, groceries, utilities, and car payments. We also set aside money for savings, and I try to contribute to a college fund for the kids, even if it's a small amount each month. It's not always easy to stick to the budget, especially when unexpected things come up, but Mei and I have gotten pretty good at adjusting and prioritizing what's most important. I think the key is being flexible but also staying disciplined, because we both know that providing for our kids means planning ahead and being responsible with our money.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

David Lee: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment in Capitol Hill, and while it's not the biggest place, it's comfortable and convenient for our family. Rent here is pretty high—around $2,200 a month—but it's manageable because we've been careful with our budget and we both work. I think renting has been the right choice for us right now, especially with the kids still in school and the uncertainty of the future. We've been in the same building for about five years, and the landlord is pretty understanding. It's a good neighborhood, and I feel like we're in a stable situation. Plus, it gives us the flexibility to move if we ever need to, which is something I value. I know some people dream of owning a home, but for us, renting has worked well so far, and I don't see any reason to change that unless our circumstances shift significantly.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

David Lee: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the kids' schedules. For example, during the winter months, our utility bills—especially heating—went up a bit, which was a noticeable change from the milder fall and spring months. We also had higher grocery expenses around the holidays, like Thanksgiving and Christmas, when we tend to cook bigger meals and buy more snacks for the kids. School-related costs also vary—when the kids are in session, we have more fees for activities and supplies, but during summer, those drop off, though we end up spending more on things like summer camps or family trips. Another thing that affected our budget was the timing of our car maintenance. We had to replace the tires in the middle of the year, which wasn't in our regular monthly plan, so that added a bit of unexpected expense. Overall, I've learned to be more flexible with our budget and to set aside a little extra each month for these kinds of surprises. It's not always perfect, but it helps us stay afloat without getting too stressed about it.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and I have grown through the challenges of the past year. It reminded me of how important it is to lean on each other during tough times, whether it's my wife helping me with the kids or my kids learning to be more independent. It also made me think about how my own mental health and emotional well-being have shaped the way I parent and interact with my family. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but now I see that asking for help is a strength, not a weakness. It also brought up how I don't rely on social media for support, but instead on the real, meaningful connections I have with the people I love. I'm grateful for the support system I've built and for the lessons I've learned about resilience, balance, and the importance of being present for the people who matter most.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

David Lee: I do save, and it's something I've made a priority, especially after realizing how important it is to plan for the future. We have a joint savings account that we both contribute to every month, even if it's just a small amount. I think of it as a way to build a safety net for the kids' education, for unexpected expenses, and for our own peace of mind. Mei and I also have separate emergency funds, which we keep in cash or in a high-yield savings account. It's not always easy to set money aside when there are so many competing needs, but we've made it a habit—like paying our bills or going to the grocery store. I remember when I was younger, I didn't think about saving much because I was focused on just getting by. But now, with the kids and the responsibilities we have, it's become a non-negotiable part of our routine. I also try to teach Lily and Ethan about saving, even in small ways, like putting aside some of their allowance for something they want. It's not about being rich—it's about being prepared, and I think that's a lesson I want them to carry with them as they grow up.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

David Lee: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for the future of my kids. We've been contributing to a college fund for Lily and Ethan, even if it's just a small amount each month. I think it's important to start early, even if it's not a lot, because compound interest can add up over time. We also have an emergency fund that we've been building up, which gives us peace of mind in case of unexpected expenses—like the tire replacement we had earlier this year. I've learned that saving isn't just about big goals; it's about creating a sense of security for the family. It's not always easy, especially when we're juggling so many things, but I believe it's one of the most responsible things we can do as parents. I want my kids to grow up knowing that planning for the future is just as important as enjoying the present.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

David Lee: I work as a civil engineer for a mid-sized firm here in Seattle, specializing in infrastructure projects like roads, bridges, and public transit systems. My job involves a mix of design, planning, and on-site inspections, so I spend a good portion of my week in meetings or reviewing blueprints, but I also get out into the field quite a bit. I enjoy the hands-on aspect of it—seeing a project go from a concept on paper to something tangible that people use every day. One of the most important parts of my job is ensuring that the structures we build are safe and durable, especially since they serve the community my kids will grow up in. I also work closely with city planners, contractors, and other engineers to make sure everything aligns with both the technical requirements and the needs of the people who will use these facilities. It's not always easy—there are deadlines, budget constraints, and sometimes unexpected challenges—but I find it rewarding because I know my work helps shape the environment we live in. I've been in this field for over a decade now, and I've learned that being a good engineer isn't just about the technical skills—it's also about communication, problem-solving, and understanding the bigger picture of how infrastructure impacts everyday life.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

David Lee: I usually work around 40 to 45 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the project. Some weeks are more demanding, especially when we're in the final stages of a project or dealing with unexpected delays. I start my day around 7:30 a.m., and I'm usually in the office by 8:30. My job requires a lot of collaboration—whether it's with city officials, contractors, or other engineers—so I spend a good portion of my time in meetings or reviewing blueprints. I also do a fair amount of on-site work, which means I might be out in the field inspecting construction sites or talking to workers. I try to leave work around 6 or 7 p.m. so I can be home for dinner with the family. It's a demanding job, but I find it rewarding because I know my work helps shape the community my kids will grow up in. I've been in this field for over a decade now, and I've learned that being a good engineer isn't just about the technical skills—it's also about communication, problem-solving, and understanding the bigger picture of how infrastructure impacts everyday life.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

David Lee: No, I haven't had more than one job throughout most of my life. I've always focused on building a stable career, and being a civil engineer has been my main source of income. That said, there were a few years early in my career when I took on part-time tutoring work on weekends to help support my family while I was still paying off student loans. It wasn't easy balancing that with my full-time job and being a new father, but it taught me a lot about time management and the value of every dollar. I think those experiences helped shape my work ethic and my approach to providing for my family. Now, with the kids growing up and my career more established, I'm able to focus more on being present for them without needing to take on extra work. It's a different kind of challenge now—raising kids and maintaining a career—but I wouldn't trade it for anything.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my family and I have grown through the challenges of the past year. It reminded me of how important it is to lean on each other during tough times, whether it's my wife helping me with the kids or my kids learning to be more independent. It also made me think about how my own mental health and emotional well-being have shaped the way I parent and interact with my family. I used to think I had to handle everything on my own, but now I see that asking for help is a strength, not a weakness. It also brought up how I don't rely on social media for support, but instead on the real, meaningful connections I have with the people I love. I'm grateful for the support system I've built and for the lessons I've learned about resilience, balance, and the importance of being present for the people who matter most.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

David Lee: In total, our household made around $8,500 last month. I earn a salary as a civil engineer, and Mei works part-time as a translator, which helps cover some of our expenses. While it's not a huge amount, it's enough to manage our bills, save a little, and provide for the kids. I've always believed that financial stability comes from a combination of hard work, smart planning, and being mindful of our spending. It's not always easy, especially with the rising cost of living in Seattle, but we've found a way to make it work. I think the most important thing is that we're not living paycheck to paycheck, and we have some savings to fall back on if needed. It's a good balance for us right now, and I'm proud of how we've built a life that's both stable and full of opportunities for our kids.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

David Lee: I've been at my current job for about eight years now, and I've really grown into the role over time. The company offers a solid benefits package, which includes health insurance for me, my wife, and the kids. That's been a huge relief, especially with the rising cost of healthcare. We also get paid time off, including vacation days, sick leave, and a few personal days, which is important for maintaining a work-life balance. I've taken advantage of the vacation days to plan family trips, like a camping trip to Olympic National Park last summer, which was a great way to disconnect and recharge. The company also offers some professional development opportunities, like workshops and courses that help us stay updated on the latest engineering practices. I've taken a few of those, which has been helpful in advancing my career. Overall, I feel lucky to be in a stable position that supports both my family and my professional growth.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

David Lee: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager, who I've known for several years now. He's supportive and understands the demands of balancing work with family life, which is something I really appreciate. He's given me the freedom to manage my time in a way that works for me, as long as I meet the project deadlines. As for my coworkers, we get along well—there's a good mix of people with different backgrounds and experiences, which makes the workplace environment dynamic and collaborative. I've been lucky to work with some really talented engineers who are not only skilled but also passionate about what they do. We often have lunch together or grab coffee after work, which helps build a sense of camaraderie. I think the key to having good relationships at work is mutual respect and communication, and I've always tried to embody that. It makes the job more enjoyable and less stressful, which is important when you're trying to juggle so many responsibilities outside of work.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

David Lee: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there are some variations depending on the project. Most days, I start around 7:30 a.m. and work until 6 or 7 p.m., which gives me enough time to be home for dinner with the kids. I do have some flexibility, especially when it comes to arriving at the office or leaving a bit earlier if I need to pick up the kids from school or attend a family event. That said, there are times when the schedule gets less predictable, especially when we're working on tight deadlines or dealing with unexpected issues on a project. For example, if there's a problem with a construction site or a change in city regulations, I might need to stay late or come in early to address it. I appreciate the flexibility my job offers, but I also value the structure it provides, especially with my family life. It's a balance, but one that I've learned to manage over the years.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

David Lee: Overall, I feel pretty stable about my financial situation. We're not rolling in money, but we're not struggling either. It's a tightrope walk sometimes, especially with the cost of living here in Seattle, but I think we've found a good balance. Mei and I both work, which helps, and we've been careful with our budgeting. I know there are days when I worry about the future—like whether we'll be able to afford college for the kids or if something unexpected happens—but I also know that we've built a life that's secure enough for now. I've come a long way from that small apartment where we didn't have much, and I'm proud of how far we've come. It's not about being rich; it's about being responsible, and I think that's something I want to teach my kids. As long as we keep working hard, staying mindful of our spending, and supporting each other, I believe we'll be okay.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work life have shaped my daily experiences and long-term goals. Thinking about how our bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me of the importance of flexibility and planning—whether it's preparing for seasonal changes, holidays, or unexpected expenses like car maintenance. It also made me appreciate how far we've come financially, from the days of tight budgets and multiple jobs to now, where we're able to provide for our family without constantly living paycheck to paycheck. When I talked about my savings and how we've been setting money aside for the kids' future, it brought up how much I value financial responsibility and the peace of mind that comes with it. It also made me think about my job as a civil engineer—not just as a source of income, but as a way to contribute to the community and ensure a stable future for my family. Overall, it was a meaningful exercise to look back on these aspects of my life and realize how much they contribute to the stability and security I now have.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

David Lee: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were different. My father worked at a factory for many years, and while it wasn't a high-paying job, he was always reliable and showed up every day, no matter what. He didn't have much formal education, but he had a strong work ethic, and I think that's something he passed down to me. My mother, on the other hand, worked multiple jobs at times—she was a cleaner, a part-time cashier, and even did some sewing work from home. She always said she wanted to give me and my brother a better life than she had, and she worked hard to make that happen. I remember seeing her come home tired but still smiling, always making sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. Their sacrifices didn't go unnoticed, and I think that's why I've always valued hard work and education so much. It wasn't just about money for them—it was about providing stability and opportunities for their children, and I hope I'm doing the same for my kids today.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

David Lee: My father worked at a factory that manufactured automotive parts. His most important duties involved operating heavy machinery and ensuring that the production line ran smoothly. He was known for his attention to detail and his ability to fix equipment when something went wrong. Even though the work was physically demanding and the pay wasn't great, he always showed up on time and gave his best effort. My mother, on the other hand, worked as a cleaner in a local office building during the day and did part-time sewing work from home in the evenings. Her most important activities were making sure our household had enough food, keeping our small apartment clean, and helping me with my homework whenever she could. She also took on extra jobs during the holidays or when bills were due, which I remember was a big sacrifice for her. Looking back, I realize how much they both gave up to provide for us, and it's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

David Lee: My father worked for a local manufacturing company that supplied parts to automotive industries. It was a small but steady business, and he was one of the main workers on the production line. The company wasn't huge, but it provided him with a regular paycheck, which was a big deal for our family back then. My mother worked for a small office building management company as a cleaner. She would clean the floors, restrooms, and common areas, and she did it with such care that the office manager even thanked her by name sometimes. In the evenings, she would sew clothes or do alterations from home, mostly for neighbors who couldn't afford to go to a tailor. I remember her working late into the night, sometimes with the kids asleep, just to make sure we had enough to get by. Looking back, I realize how much they both gave up—my father working long hours in a hot, noisy factory, and my mother taking on extra work just so we could have a better life. Their sacrifices didn't go unnoticed, and I think that's why I've always valued hard work and education so much. It wasn't just about money for them—it was about providing stability and opportunities for their children, and I hope I'm doing the same for my kids today.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

David Lee: A few years from now, I hope my life is still centered around my family, but maybe with a little more balance and less stress. I want my kids to be happy, healthy, and well-educated, and I hope they grow up to be the kind of people who value hard work, kindness, and community. I also hope I'm still doing work that matters—maybe I'll have the chance to take on more leadership roles in my engineering career or even mentor young people who are just starting out, like I was once mentored. I want to be present for my kids' big moments, whether it's their first day of school, their graduation, or just their everyday triumphs. I also hope we're still living in a place that feels like home, maybe with a little more space, but I don't think it has to be bigger—it just has to be a place where we feel safe, connected, and supported. I think the most important thing is that I'm still growing as a person, learning from life, and being there for the people I love. That's what I hope for, and I think as long as I keep working hard and staying true to the values that shaped me, I can make that future a reality.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

David Lee: What I value the most in my life is family—my wife, my kids, and my parents. They are the foundation of everything I do. I also value hard work and education, because I know how much those things have shaped my life and given me the opportunities I have today. I value the sense of community in Capitol Hill, the people who live here, and the way we look out for each other. I value the little moments, like watching my kids play in the park or having a quiet dinner with my wife. I value the lessons I've learned through challenges, like my knee injury or the times I felt overwhelmed with work and family. Most of all, I value the ability to grow, to learn from my mistakes, and to be there for the people I love. I think life is about more than just getting by—it's about making meaningful connections, contributing to something bigger than yourself, and being present for the people who matter most.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work and financial situation have shaped my daily life and long-term goals. Thinking about my current job as a civil engineer reminded me of how far I've come from that small apartment in Seattle, where my parents worked hard to give me opportunities. It also made me appreciate the stability and benefits that come with my job, like health insurance and paid time off, which are things I never took for granted growing up. When I talked about my relationships at work, it brought up how important it is to have a supportive manager and coworkers who understand the challenges of balancing work and family life. It also made me realize how much I value the flexibility my job offers, even though it's not always perfect. Overall, it was a meaningful exercise to look back on these aspects of my life and realize how much they contribute to the stability and security I now have.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective journey for me. It reminded me of how far I've come—from growing up in a small apartment in Seattle with parents who worked tirelessly to provide for us, to making the conscious choice to pursue education despite financial struggles, and eventually building a life that I'm proud of today. It's amazing how the values instilled in me by my parents—hard work, education, and family—continue to shape the way I raise my children and navigate my daily life. Reflecting on my career as a civil engineer, the challenges I've faced, and the support I've received from my wife, friends, and community, I feel a deep sense of gratitude. This process has shown me how interconnected my past, present, and future are, and how the choices I've made, both big and small, have led me to where I am now. I'm proud of the person I've become, and I hope to pass on the same resilience, values, and love to my children as they grow up.
